36.2: “Wait for me a little longer, and I will show you that there is yet more to be said for God.
36.3: I bring my learning from far away, and will tell how right and good my Maker is.
36.4: For sure my words are not false. One who is perfect in much learning is with you.
36.5: “See, God is powerful, but does not hate anyone. He is powerful in strength of understanding.
36.6: He does not keep the sinful alive, but gives what is right and fair to those who are troubled.
36.7: He does not turn His eyes away from those who are right with Him. He puts them on the throne with kings and they are honored forever.
36.8: If they are tied up in chains and caught in the ropes of trouble,
36.9: then He makes known to them their work and their sins, that they have shown pride.
36.10: He makes them listen to teaching, and tells them to turn away from sin.
36.11: If they hear and serve Him, the rest of their days will be filled with what they need and their years with peace.
36.12: But if they do not hear, they will die by the sword. They will die without learning.
36.13: “But those who do not know God keep anger in their heart. They do not cry for help when He puts them in chains.
36.14: They die when they are young. And their life ends among those who sell the use of their bodies in the houses of the false gods.
36.15: He takes those who suffer out of their suffering. He speaks to them in times of trouble.
36.16: He led you from being close to trouble to a wide place where you were free with your table full of food.
36.17: “But you wanted to punish the sinful. Punishment and being fair have taken hold of you.
36.18: Be careful or anger will tempt you to laugh at the truth. Do not take pay in secret for wrong-doing and be turned aside.
36.19: Will your riches or all your power keep you from trouble?
36.20: Do not desire the night, when people are taken from their place.
36.21: Be careful, do not turn to sin. For you have chosen this instead of suffering.
36.22: See, God is honored in His power. Who is a teacher like Him?
36.23: Who has told Him the way He should go? And who has said, ‘You have done wrong’?
36.24: “Remember that you should honor His work, of which men have sung.
36.25: All men have seen it. Man sees it from far away.
36.26: See, God is honored, and we do not know Him. We are not able to know the number of His years.
36.27: For He takes up the drops of water that become rain,
36.28: which the clouds pour down. Much rain falls on man.
36.29: Can anyone understand how the clouds are spread out, or how He thunders from His tent?
36.30: See, He spreads His lightning around Him and covers the bottom of the sea.
36.31: For by these He judges the people and He gives much food.
36.32: He covers His hands with the lightning, and tells it to hit the mark.
36.33: His thunder tells of a storm coming, and cattle also know it is coming.

37.1: “At this my heart shakes with fear and jumps from its place.
37.2: Listen to the thunder of His voice and the noise that comes from His mouth.
37.3: He lets it loose under the whole heaven. He lets His lightning go to the ends of the earth.
37.4: His voice sounds after it. He thunders with His great and powerful voice. And He does not hold back the lightning when His voice is heard.
37.5: God thunders with His great voice. He does great things which we cannot understand.
37.6: For He says to the snow, ‘Fall on the earth,’ and to the rain, ‘Be strong.’
37.7: He stops the work of every man, that all men may know His work.
37.8: Then the wild animals go to their holes, and stay where they live.
37.9: The storm comes from the south, and the cold from the north.
37.10: Water becomes ice by the breath of God. The wide waters become ice.
37.11: He loads the heavy clouds with water and they send out His lightning.
37.12: It changes its path and turns around by His leading, doing whatever He tells it to do on the earth where people live.
37.13: He causes it to happen for punishment, or for His world, or because of His love.
37.14: “Hear this, O Job. Stop and think about the great works of God.
37.15: Do you know how God does them, and makes the lightning shine from His cloud?
37.16: Do you know how the clouds are set in heaven, the great works of Him Who is perfect in understanding?
37.17: Do you know why you are hot in your clothes when the land becomes quiet because of the south wind?
37.18: Can you help Him spread out the sky, making it as hard as a mirror made from heated brass?
37.19: Teach us what we should say to Him. We cannot put words together to help us because of darkness.
37.20: Should He be told that I want to speak? Did a man ever wish to be swallowed up?
37.21: “Now men cannot look on the light when it is bright in the sky, when the wind has passed and made it clear.
37.22: A bright gold light is seen in the north. Around God is great power.
37.23: We cannot come near the All-powerful. He is lifted high with power. And He is right and fair and good and will not make it hard for us.
37.24: So men honor Him with fear. He has respect for any who are wise in heart.”

38.1: Then the Lord answered Job out of the strong wind and said,
38.2: “Who is this that makes words of wisdom dark by speaking without much learning?
38.3: Now get ready like a man, and I will ask you some questions and you answer Me.
38.4: Where were you when I began building the earth? Tell Me, if you have understanding.
38.5: Who decided how big it was to be, since you know? Who looked to see if it was as big as it should be?
38.6: What was it built upon? Who laid its first stone,
38.7: when the morning stars sang together and all the sons of God called out for joy?
38.8: “Who shut up the sea with doors, when it rushed out from its secret place?
38.9: I made clouds its clothing, and put much darkness around it.
38.10: I marked the places where it could not pass, and set locks and doors.
38.11: And I said, ‘You will come this far, and no farther. Here will your proud waves stop.’
38.12: “Have you ever in your life told the morning when to come, and caused the first light of day to know its place,
38.13: that it might take hold of the ends of the earth, and the sinful be shaken out of it?
38.14: It is changed like clay when an object is pushed down to mark it, and they stand out like clothing.
38.15: The light of the sinful is held back, and the arm lifted up is broken.
38.16: “Have you gone into the wells of the sea? Have you walked on the bottom of the deep sea?
38.17: Have the gates of death been shown to you? Or have you seen the gates of the deep darkness?
38.18: Have you understood how great the earth is? Tell Me, if you know all this.
38.19: “Where does the light come from? And where is the place of darkness,
38.20: that you may take it to its land, and know the paths to its home?
38.21: You know, for you were born then. You are very old!
38.22: Have you gone into the store-houses of the snow? Have you seen the store-houses of the hail,
38.23: which I have kept for the time of trouble, for the day of war and battle?
38.24: What is the way to the place where the light is divided, or the east wind spread over the earth?
38.25: “Who has cut open a way for the flood, and a path for the thunderstorm?
38.26: Who brings rain on the land without people, on a desert without a man in it,
38.27: to fill the need of the wasted land, and to make the grass grow?
38.28: Does the rain have a father? Who has given birth to the drops of rain?
38.29: Who gave birth to ice? And who gave birth to the snow water of heaven?
38.30: Water becomes hard like stone, and the top of the sea is covered with ice.
38.31: “Can you tie the chains of the stars of Pleiades, or loose the ropes of Orion?
38.32: Can you lead the groups of stars out at the right times? Can you lead the stars of the Bear with her young?
38.33: Do you know the laws of the heavens? Can you make them to rule over the earth?
38.34: “Can you lift up your voice to the clouds, that a flood of water may cover you?
38.35: Can you send out lightnings, that they may go and say to you, ‘Here we are’?
38.36: Who has given wisdom to the heart? Who has given understanding to the mind?
38.37: Who can number the clouds by wisdom? Or who can push over the water jars of the heavens,
38.38: when the dust gathers together and becomes hard?
38.39: “Can you hunt food for the lion? Can you fill the hunger of the young lions,
38.40: when they lie in their own place in the rock, or wait in their hiding place?
38.41: Who gets the food ready for the raven, when its young cry to God and go about without food?

39.1: “Do you know when the mountain goats give birth? Do you watch the deer giving birth?
39.2: Can you number the months that they carry their young? Or do you know the time when their young are born?
39.3: They get down and give birth to their young, and get rid of their pains.
39.4: Their young ones become strong. They grow up in the open field. They leave and do not return to them.
39.5: “Who has let the wild donkey go free? Who has taken off the ropes which held the fast donkey?
39.6: I gave him the desert for a home, and the salt land for a place to live.
39.7: He hates the noise of the city. He does not hear the calls of the man who drives him.
39.8: He goes looking for grass to eat on the mountains. He looks for every green thing.
39.9: Will the wild ox be willing to serve you? Will he stay through the night by the food you give him to eat?
39.10: Can you tie the wild ox to a plow in the field? Will he follow you to plow the valleys?
39.11: Will you trust in him because he is very strong, and leave your work to him?
39.12: Will you trust him to return and bring your grain to your grain-floor?
39.13: “The wings of the ostrich wave with joy, but are they the wings of love?
39.14: For she leaves her eggs to the earth and lets them get warm in the dust.
39.15: She forgets that a foot might crush them, or that the wild animal may step on them.
39.16: She is bad in the way she acts toward her young, as if they were not hers. Her work of giving birth is for nothing, for she does not care.
39.17: Because God has not given her wisdom or her share of understanding.
39.18: When she begins to run, she laughs at the horse and the horseman.
39.19: “Do you give the horse his strength? Do you dress his neck with long hair?
39.20: Do you make him jump like the locust? The powerful noise he makes with his nostrils fills men with fear.
39.21: He hits his foot against the ground in the valley, and has joy in his strength. He goes out to meet the battle.
39.22: He laughs at fear and is not afraid. He does not turn back from the sword.
39.23: The arrows and spears he carries make noise as they hit together.
39.24: He runs fast over the ground with shaking and anger. He cannot stand still at the sound of the horn.
39.25: When the horn sounds, he laughs without fear. He smells the battle from far away. He hears the thunder of the captains, and the war cry.
39.26: “Is it by your understanding that the hawk flies, spreading his wings toward the south?
39.27: Is it because the eagle is obeying you that he flies high and makes his nest in a high place?
39.28: He lives on a high rock. His strong place is on the mountain-top that is hard to reach.
39.29: From there he looks for his food. His eyes see it from far away.
39.30: He is where dead bodies are and his young ones drink the blood.”

40.1: Then the Lord said to Job,
40.2: “Will one who finds fault not agree with the All-powerful? He who speaks strong words against God, let him answer.”
40.3: Job answered the Lord and said,
40.4: “See, I am not important. What can I answer You? I put my hand on my mouth.
40.5: I have spoken once, and I cannot answer; even twice, and I have no more to say.”
40.6: Then the Lord answered out of the storm, and said,
40.7: “Get ready like a man. I will ask you, and you answer Me.
40.8: Will you say what I decide is wrong? Will you say that I have done wrong, that you may be made right?
40.9: Do you have an arm like God? Can you thunder with a voice like His?
40.10: “Dress yourself with shining-greatness and great power. Cover yourself with honor and greatness.
40.11: Pour out your anger that is flowing over. Look on everyone who is proud, and put him to shame.
40.12: Look on everyone who is proud, and bring him down. Crush the sinful where they stand.
40.13: Hide them all in the dust together. Shut them up in the hidden place.
40.14: Then I will also tell you that your own right hand can save you.
40.15: “See now the hippopotamus, which I made as well as you. He eats grass like an ox.
40.16: See, his strength is in his body. His power is in his stomach.
40.17: He moves his tail like a cedar tree. His legs are made very strong.
40.18: His bones are like brass. His legs are like pieces of iron.
40.19: “He is the first of the works of God. Let his maker bring him his sword.
40.20: For sure the mountains bring food to him where all the animals of the field play.
40.21: He lies down under the lotus plants, hidden in the high river grass.
40.22: He lies in the shadow of the lotus plants, with the willow trees of the river around him.
40.23: If a river flows over, he is not afraid. He is sure of himself even if the Jordan rushes against his mouth.
40.24: Can anyone take him when he is watching? Can anyone catch him and put a ring in his nose?

41.1: “Can you pull the crocodile out with a fish-hook? Can you tie his tongue down with a rope?
41.2: Can you put a rope in his nose, or put a hook through his jaw?
41.3: Will he beg you to be good to him? Will he speak soft words to you?
41.4: Will he make an agreement with you to take him and make him your servant forever?
41.5: Will you play with him as if he were a bird? Or will you put him on a rope for your young women?
41.6: Will traders talk about buying and selling him? Will they divide him among the store-keepers?
41.7: Can you fill his skin or his head with fish spears?
41.8: Lay your hand on him, and remember the battle. You will not do it again!
41.9: See, the hope of man is false. One is laid low even when seeing him.
41.10: No one is so powerful that he would wake him. Who then can stand before Me?
41.11: Who has given Me everything, that I should pay him back? Whatever is under the whole heaven is Mine.
41.12: “I will not keep quiet about his legs, or his powerful strength, or the good way he is made.
41.13: Who can take off his outside clothing? Who can get through his hard skin?
41.14: Who can open the doors of his mouth? Around his teeth is much fear.
41.15: His hard covering is his pride. He is shut up as with a lock.
41.16: One piece of his hard skin is so close to another that no air can come between them.
41.17: They are joined one to another. They hold on to each other and cannot be separated.
41.18: His breath gives out light. And his eyes are like those of the first light of day.
41.19: Burning light goes out of his mouth. Fire comes out.
41.20: Smoke goes out of his nostrils, as from a boiling pot and burning grass.
41.21: His breath sets fire to coals. A fire goes out of his mouth.
41.22: Strength is in his neck, and fear jumps in front of him.
41.23: The folds of his flesh are joined together. They are set in place and cannot be moved.
41.24: His heart is as hard as a stone, even as hard as a grinding-stone.
41.25: When he raises himself up, the powerful are afraid. They are troubled because of his noise.
41.26: The sword that hits him cannot cut. And spears are of no use.
41.27: He thinks of iron as straw, and brass as soft wood.
41.28: The arrow cannot make him run away. Stones thrown at him are like dry grass to him.
41.29: He thinks of heavy sticks as dry grass. He laughs at the noise of the spear.
41.30: The parts under him are like sharp pieces of a pot. He spreads out like a grain crusher on the mud.
41.31: He makes the sea boil like a pot. He makes the sea like a jar of oil.
41.32: He makes his way shine behind him. One would think that the sea has white hair.
41.33: Nothing on earth is like him, one made without fear.
41.34: He looks on everything that is high. He is king over all that are proud.”

42.1: Then Job answered the Lord, and said,
42.2: “I know that You can do all things. Nothing can put a stop to Your plans.
42.3: ‘Who is this that hides words of wisdom without much learning?’ I have said things that I did not understand, things too great for me, which I did not know.
42.4: ‘Hear now, and I will speak. I will ask you, and you answer Me.’
42.5: I had heard of You only by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees You.
42.6: So I hate the things that I have said. And I put dust and ashes on myself to show how sorry I am.”
42.7: After the Lord had spoken these words to Job, the Lord said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My anger burns against you and your two friends, because you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.
42.8: So now take seven bulls and seven rams, and go to My servant Job. Give a burnt gift for yourselves, and My servant Job will pray for you. For I will hear his prayer and not punish you for being foolish, because you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.”
42.9: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite, did what the Lord told them. And the Lord heard Job’s prayer.
42.10: The Lord returned to Job all the things that he had lost, when he prayed for his friends. The Lord gave Job twice as much as he had before.
42.11: Then all his brothers and sisters and all who had known him before came to him, and ate bread with him in his house. They showed pity and comforted him for all the trouble the Lord had brought upon him. Each one gave him one piece of money and a gold ring.
42.12: The Lord brought more good to Job in his later years than in his beginning. He had 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 2,000 oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.
42.13: He had seven sons and three daughters also.
42.14: He gave the first the name Jemimah, the second Keziah, and the third Keren-happuch.
42.15: No women were found in all the land who were as beautiful as Job’s daughters. And their father gave them a share among their brothers.
42.16: After this Job lived 140 years, and saw his sons, his grandsons, and even their sons.
42.17: Then Job died, an old man having lived many days.
